div.p: S. P. Your previous letter of kindness, dated the sixth of October, was delivered to my wife in my absence, along with a silver shekel, and I received them only after returning home almost a full month later. This is the reason why I have been slow to respond to them until now. I express my utmost gratitude to your excellence for the transmitted shekel, which you, when I requested a lead one, chose to give in silver, thereby binding me to you completely with your generosity and munificence. However, I wish (since you have long received the list of my coins) to understand from you whether there are any among mine that your kindness would desire; indeed, I would ensure that they are formed and returned to you from mine as you wish. At present, to declare myself grateful in some way, I send to your excellence a Nicophorus formed from a golden archetype, a coin not of ancient Roman antiquity, but Constantinopolitan, struck by a Christian emperor. In the inscription on the other side, where two images are seen, I cannot, after these letters [Greek], gather the rest to have any meaning. If your kindness can make sense of them, I ask you to communicate it to me at your leisure.

I also thank you for the booklet, namely the Summa of true religion, presented to me in your name by Mr. Froschauer; I did not receive the other from the Gesner brothers. However, I wish to reciprocate and serve your kindness in any way I can and ask that you do not doubt my benevolent mind towards you and keep me in your commendation. Farewell, most distinguished and esteemed man.
Given at Frankfurt on the calends of April in the year etc. 56.
